snippets.label: Presenting Complaint
snippets.content: Patient presents with a unilateral rash, consistent with shingles. Onset of rash was [2] days ago. Prodromal symptoms of {pain|tingling|burning} in the affected area for [1-2] days prior. The rash is located on the [dermatome, e.g., T4 on the right].

snippets.label: Red Flag Assessment
snippets.content: Red flag screen: No eye involvement (pain, redness, visual changes). No facial droop or hearing loss. Not pregnant. Not severely immunocompromised (e.g., recent chemotherapy, organ transplant). No signs of systemic illness (fever, confusion).

snippets.label: Rash Examination
snippets.content: Unilateral vesicular rash on an erythematous base, located in the [dermatome] dermatome. The rash does not cross the midline. Lesions are at the {vesicular*|pustular|crusting} stage. No signs of secondary bacterial infection (e.g., spreading erythema, purulent discharge).

snippets.label: Treatment Plan (Supply)
snippets.content: Patient meets criteria for treatment under the Pharmacy First PGD. Supplied Aciclovir 800mg five times daily for 7 days. Advised on importance of adherence and completing the course. Pain management advice given (paracetamol/ibuprofen). Safety netting and self-care advice provided.

snippets.label: Referral Plan
snippets.content: Patient does not meet criteria for treatment under the Pharmacy First PGD due to [reason, e.g., rash onset >7 days, ophthalmic involvement]. Referred to GP for further assessment and management. Self-care and safety netting advice provided.

snippets.label: Safety Netting
snippets.content: Advised to seek urgent medical attention (A&E/999) if: rash spreads to the eyes, develops facial weakness, becomes systemically unwell (fever, confusion), or if pain is severe and uncontrolled. Advised to contact GP if lesions show signs of bacterial infection or if not improving after treatment.

discriminators: Time since rash onset (<72 hours vs <7 days vs >7 days)
Location of rash (truncal vs. ophthalmic vs. head/neck)
redFlags: Eye involvement (Hutchinson's sign - vesicles on the tip of the nose, side, or root of the nose)
Altered mental state, confusion, or severe headache
Known severe immunosuppression (e.g., recent chemotherapy, organ transplant)

references.label: NHS England Pharmacy First PGD: Shingles
Clinical Pathways UK: Pharmacy First - Shingles

illnessScript.summary: Shingles (herpes zoster) is a reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, causing a painful, unilateral vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. The Pharmacy First service allows community pharmacists to assess and treat eligible adults (18+) to reduce severity and prevent complications like post-herpetic neuralgia.

redFlags: Vesicles on the tip, side, or root of the nose (Hutchinson's sign)
Eye pain, redness, or visual disturbance
mustNotMiss.whyDangerous: Can lead to permanent vision loss.
mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Urgent same-day referral to an ophthalmologist.

discriminators.question: When did the rash first appear?
discriminators.reasoning: Treatment is most effective within 72 hours. The PGD has specific criteria for treatment between 72 hours and 7 days.
discriminators.clinicalValue: Determines eligibility for antiviral treatment under the PGD.

whenHelpful.rationale: Shingles is a clinical diagnosis in the community pharmacy setting.

whenNotNeeded.rationale: Diagnosis is clinical in most cases in a community pharmacy setting.

selfCare: Keep the rash clean and dry
Use a cool compress for pain relief

pharmacologicalConcepts.considerations: Aciclovir 800mg 5 times a day for 7 days is the standard PGD treatment.

followUpLogic: Advise to see GP if pain persists after the rash has healed (for PHN assessment).

returnAdvice: Signs of secondary bacterial infection (pus, spreading redness)

termMap.description: Vesicles on the tip of the nose, indicating ophthalmic involvement
